remixed_from.title: Parametric pulley - lots of tooth profiles

description.text:
this holds the pulley for the x-belt.
in the original design, witch the rods where only stucked in, was most of the tension directed over the z-bearings, z-rods and frame.
this presses directly onto the x-rods, witch have a blind-hole on the other end.

'connectet by shape' rather than '- - force' ²

originaly it was desinged fro a selfprinted pulley³ on 2 HDD-bearings.
i went back to the 4mm rimmed bearings, so i had to file .3mm of of the contact area.
if you also need 8mm, but dont want to change it in the .dwg, just stetch the x-axis to 105% and file off at least .1mm.

the holes are a bit bigger than standard for metric-threat-forming.
so it should be possible to screw them into the part directly after printing.

aditional parts:
2 M8x30 (exact length to be measured on your printer)
(maybe 2 small pieces of rubber or plastic, so the rods dont corrode where they come in contact with other metals.
maybe also filing the tips of the screws straight.)
1 M3x15 / M3x16
all preferably stainless.
bearings and/or pulleys.

ps.:
²can anyone tell me the correct english words for 'kraftschlüssig / formschlüssig'

³some manufracturers advise you to use bearings for diameters over 40mm (63teeth).
in my experiance they suffice down to 20 teeth,
and below that pulleys are that inpercise (especialy selvprinted ones), that you are still better off with a plane old bearing.

(i'm always using ² & ³, since my keyboard dosn't have keys for ^1 or ^4)

and do not print those pulleys.

maybee i will redising it oneday myself since it was desinged for a 17teeth-pulley, and the bearings have a diameter eqivalent to 20 teeth.

nozzle .4mm @220°
bed 50° (+maskingband)
shell .8mm
100% infill
50mm/s
no brimm

This wind turbine can produce electricity!
The wind turns the turbine and cause a LED to light up.
The stronger the wind blows, the brighter the LED lights.

I have already tested at the wind turbine it works very well. The wind turbine is already turning at the slightest wind but the LED only lights up at a slightly higher speed.
So this wind turbine is a storm-warning device.

The Motor diameter is 23mm, height is 12,8mm and the shaft is 2mm.
Bearing: DIN 625 SKF (outer diameter : 16mm; inner diameter 8mm).

This project is still in progress!

The roof was printed in Red PLA with 0.20 layer thickness an 20% infill and no support.

The Mainbody was printed in Red PLA with 0.20 layer thickness an 20% infill and with support from the printing tabl.

The Gears have been printed in yellow PLA 0.15 layer thickness an 20% infill and no support.

The PLA has a very poor quality "el cheapo" but I can afford no better quality.

This would be best printed in ABS. PLA will likely soon melt and distort from the heat from the sun.

More information coming soon…

Quadror blocks were conceived as a folding support structure. They are composed by 4 L-shaped identical parts that are glued/bolted two by two. This model will print this 4 parts together already assembled. Unfolded quadrors may be placed side by side and stacked to form a wall or a pillar.

References:
Quadror site: http://www.quadror.com
Sketchup model: https://3dwarehouse.sketchup.com/model.html?id=91b5b70ad95fd58b3e232b593c642ba9
Quadror sawhorse model: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:921314

This model was meant to be printed with a 0.2 layer. I used 2 shells and 20% infill, without any support.

After printing, carefully separate the two parts with a utility knife.

Quante volte è capitato di far cadere i panni stesi dalla vicina di sotto o le mollette che saltano sempre via ... non so voi ma a me spesso o
meglio a mia moglie ;-).
E quando succede chi chiamerà ... i Ghostbusters... !!!

dopo essermi arrangiato fino adesso con quello che avevo a
disposizione con la stampante 3D ho potuto costruirmi l'attrezzo adatto o quasi è un semplice arpione a 3 punte con una piccola calamita alla base per poter afferrare le mollette, utilizzando materiali casalinghi

1) Scaricare il modello;
2) Stampare il modello;
3) Tagliare una stampella in 3 pezzi di ca 6 cm;
4) Piegare i 3 pezzi per incastrarli nel modello;
5) Inserire una piccola fune nel foro centrale della lunghezza desiderata;
6) Fissare la base con silicone e una piccola calamita;

author: smokinpuppy

title: Clip to hold a Bamboo Stylus

description.text: An add-on clip to hold my Bamboo Stylus on the side of my Motorola Xoom stock cover.  I needed some way to keep my stylus with me and realized I had a 3D printer and the case is trimmed in ABS....Voila!  A little resin bond and I'm golden.  I printed one for a co-worker in the same situation.  The nice thing is that in this location the stylus is never in the way and always accessible regardless of the way I have the cover folded.

This is designed as a friction fit to the bamboo stylus.  I did run some sandpaper around the ID to take down the general roughness of 3D printing (start/stop globs, etc.).  I printed it at 0.2 thickness and 100% fill for strength thinking the stylus would snap in and out.  Instead it is much easier to just slide it in from the end.  Printed on end with a raft to prevent tipping during prints.

comments.text: You're welcome.  1 year later and It's still working well.
comments.author: Redcboats

Stopper for window rolling shutter shades. Put a M8 screw nut inside part 1 and cover it with part 2 (use some glue to seal it good). Then use M8 screw and fix it on shutter.
Speak back

This functional platform jack prints fully assembled without supports.

UPDATE [7/21/2015]: We have uploaded an updated platform jack with stronger scissor arms, improved axles to stop the arms from separating, and a larger gap between the screw and crossbeam to fix the fusing issue. We printed the updated version with a 0.3mm layer height and 15% infill in 4 hours.

UPDATE [7/22/2015]: For anyone having problems with the scissor arms fusing together we have uploaded a modified file with the tolerance increased from 0.5 to 0.65 mm (The axle tolerance is unchanged).

This model prints fully assembled without supports. Our print time for the original model was 6 hours on a Replicator 2. We printed it with a 0.2 mm layer height, 15% infill, and a raft. The screw will be fused to the top crossbeam initially, but if you give it a clockwise twist it should separate and turn freely. Before attempting to twist the screw, inspect the print to make sure that none of the pieces are fused together.

The updated model was printed in 4 hours on a Replicator 2 with a 0.3mm layer height and 15% infill.

The jack extends 10.5 cm. The updated jack was able to support 20 pounds before failing (while fully extended).

As lone as the screw body is able to turn before the screw head is broken, you can use a big heated screw driver, use its top to melt into the end of the screw with a depth of 10mm and when its cooled down, use the screw driver to turn the screw. If the screw body is not able to turn, using the aforesaid method may break the screw body. Anyway, if you have already been prepared to give it up, have a last try.

comments.text: Works for most people.  You have to print at a slow speed and take several minutes lightly prying the two halves to get it to pop open.  I've printed 3 of them that all worked.  I don't use their cheap settings though.  I do 100% fill and .1 layer height.  Yest it takes twelve hours to print on my MP Select.  I brought it into Cura, doubled it in size and printed one more that opened quite easily.  (It took 32 hours to print.)  The whole purpose is to waste your time having fun watching it make the internal parts.  Showing off the bigger one to friends blows their mind when they find out it printed as one part.  You do have to work at it carefully for a while to get them to open right but they usually will.  Just don't print at 15% like the description says unless you are using better filaments.

comments.text: I printed at almost 2X scaling (1.94 to be exact) on my Monoprice Select V2 using PLA.  You need to slow the printer way down and set to 100% infill and .1 layer height.  Then it takes about 32-46 hours to print depending on where you beef up or down some settings.  Oh and be forewarned it will eat about 250m of filament!  You should print it on a raft.  If you are getting your prints coming loose from a raft you have either the bed not calibrated or the heat and fan cooling needs to be tinkered with.  If it's your raft that keeps coming undone and you are sure you've leveled everything, you'll need to use some glue stick or hairspray on the bed.  I have build-tac and with a little elmers glue stick it never fails to stick.  (Getting it off the bed is more the issue.)  Most of the people who are breaking theirs are either printing at the suggested 15% infill (terrible advise to recommend  that) or are just too impatient.  Also the speed is crucial.  You will need to print very slowly to be sure the parts don't fuse.  If they do, the infill is what allows them to survive prying them apart.  I never print with less than 40% infill.  Any less just invites parts to break.  Of course it takes so darn long to print that I've only printed one big one.  I just can't spare 2 fulls days and nights for a single print very often.  While my printer can print 2 times faster, it tends to screw up tight tolerance things like this when it goes too fast.  Also don't plan on it providing any serious lifting power.  This is just a demo/toy that will break if much force is applied to it.

comments.text: I think that this is a really brilliant design and the absolute essence of what 3D printing is all about.  Frankly I didn't think that my printer (Robox) could handle printing it, but I went ahead anyway.  Unfortunately I broke some parts while trying to prize everything apart - the screw head broke off as others have found out.  Nevertheless I would say that I was 90% there.  I used ABS which I think is probably not the right material as there was a little warping at the base.  The peg did not print perfectly round which is probably why the other parts resisted my attempts to prize them apart.  Producing the bars at the top was fascinating to watch as it literally printed a long section in mid-air - even though the ends were anchored.  I printed at 30% as 15% looked far too empty.  I think a different printer and filament could produce a better result, or maybe I need to try different settings, so I will be trying again.

A scale model of one of the most beautiful bridges in the world; the Erasmus Bridge over the Maas river in Rotterdam, the Netherlands.

The model was built up using pictures and my own observation as references; I live a few minutes away and can see the 139m top from my window. It's one of the two most iconic pieces of the Rotterdam skyline, which itself is the most iconic skyline in the country.

A quote from someone in 'rival city' Amsterdam; "The Erasmus Bridge is the only thing in Rotterdam that we are jealous of."

Its dimensions are about 900mm x 140mm, which makes it somewhere around a 1:1000 scale. However, I printed at 120% (the maximum that would fit the height of my printer).

It's actually a real suspended bridge! You lace it yourself with rope. It can support a lot of weight, especially if you anchor the ends of the model.

See the tower part being printed here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TAUWoJLf1UQ

The bridge deck is not level (double curved), so you'll need some support at all the parts. Even though it's all very small, making the deck parts straight did not look good at all.

With the towering part, I suffered from oozing quite a bit. Make sure when using FDM printing techniques that you give the layers enough time to cool off, but print fast - your slicer might have a 'lift head' option, that would probably be useful in this situation (a hairy print is better than an oozed print). I had to do a lot of work to restore it (but did not get it to perfect conditions).

The circle on the ground at the tower part is there to prevent it from building a support tower all the way up to the top, while that really is not necessary for printing. You only need 'touching buildplate' support in that part

To connect the bridge deck together, I used a Dremel tool and some filament to do friction welding (google: filament friction welding). However, glueing will work as well, and might yield better results. Be careful to keep the whole bridge properly balanced, or you will not have all pillars touching the ground.
The connection between the two suspended deck parts broke on my model, as you can see in the pictures where it's next to its big brother (I had to hold it in one hand and ride my bike to the bridge in the other, which is why it gave way).

The string is a kite rope I had lying around, It's difficult to get the tension right, because you want it to look tight, but don't want it to distort the model. Drill out the holes to ensure that you can lace the rope through easily, and think of a way to secure the rope at the ends. Again, I used friction welding to make sure it would be stuck permanently.

Here is the latest iteration of my LED Cyr wheel project. A Cyr Wheel is a large metal ring that rotates gyroscopically as person 'spins' it. It acts in a similar way to a coin/penny, but every movement and motion is caused by the person inside it. I’ve been practicing for 2 years now. In 2013 I decided I want to try and put lights on it. After a couple different attempts at taping led strands I settled on the idea of a 3d printed inner cuff. Now in 2015 I’ve printed out 3 versions of an inner cuff to secure and protect leds to my wheel.

The latest model is thin, and streamlined and perfectly follows the curve of my wheel.
-It protects one strip of Ws2812B leds
-It grips the wheel well enough to stay in place
-It diffuses the Leds giving the entire cuff a glow.

The inner cuff uses approximately 50 identical “Body” pieces (depending on wheel circumference) divided into 10 piece segments. Each of these pieces are connected with 2 plugs and a dab of super glue. One segment is shorter and uses a “shorty” piece. The shorty piece closes the final gap and completes the cuff.

I have also included my last cuff design which is sturdier and uses 2 light strips divided into 5 segments. It’s definitely more “designed” with channels for lights and wires. Space for micro controllers, amplifiers and connectors. I really learned the value of Sketchup’s “follow me” tool designing this model.
You can print this cuff out using the files named Standard and Keystone.

I ultimately decided I wanted to use one piece of strip instead of individual sections and a simpler design.

A short video of the cuff in action.
https://youtu.be/WI6kjon1fL4

This is visually one of the most pleasing models I’ve printed. With a 1.5mm base and 140ish mm Z height this model seems unprintable but with the right settings it’s worry free. I recommend using a .75mm nozzle to speed up build time and increase the strength of the part. But this is not necessary. If you want to use a smaller nozzle you can use settings similar to the plastic plug guidelines below. I recommend printing 1 or 2 at a time.

PRINT THE PIECES

-To print the most current version use the Bodyv3 and
Connectorsv3 files.

CUFF PIECES
-.75mm nozzle
-.9 flow multiplier
-PLA 210C natural or white
-1.5mm walls
-.5mm layers
-1mm solid bottom and top
-no infill
-No supports
-Brim 10 lines.
-50mm/s
-heated bed not necessary

PLASTIC PLUGS
-.4mm nozzle
-1 flow multiplier
-PLA 210C natural or white
-1.2mm walls
-.2mm layers
-.8 solid bottom and top
-no infill
-40mm/s
-no support
-heated bed not necessary

ASSEMBLY

Place 2 cuff pieces on the wheel. The top of one piece slides under the base of the next. The holes will line up and the plugs will go through. I use either a lighter or small rock to press them in. Sometimes to make the holes line up, it is necessary to stretch the bottom out a bit. Especially printing with a .75mm nozzle.

Continue these steps until you have a segment 7-10 pieces long (depending on the circumference of your wheel). Carefully remove the segment from the wheel and lay it upside down with some pillows supporting it. Put a drop of super glue on each plug/tab. Let it dry

  • Create 4 segments like this.

-Place your 4 segments on the wheel and custom fit the last segment.

-Any non waterproof 5050 Led strip or smaller will fit this cuff. Wires run through a hole into the cyr wheel, connecting to a micro controller and power source. fastled.io has a very helpful library to get started coding the leds. I am using Ws2812B Led strip with a Nano Clone and 2 5v batteries in parallel. In the past I have used 5050 RGB led strip (12v) with a micro controller and 2 5v batteries in series.

title: Prusa Mendel Reprap lasercut side plates

description.text:
These are a set of side plates I designed for the Prusa Mendel to replace the 6 threaded rods and vertexes. These should make the frame more stable and easier to align.
I had these Lasercut out of 6mm MDF, then I used wood glue to glue 2 pieces together to make it stronger. (2 pieces per side, 4 pieces total).
I would recommend having it cut out of aluminum or 1/2" MDF if available. The dimensions are made to exactly replicate the original Prusa Mendel with 8mm threaded rods.
Source code is available here: https://github.com/StephS/Prusa_Plate Update:
I updated the DXF. I imported it into librecad and re-saved it to try to fix any file errors. I also increased to slot on the bottom for the Z axis support bar (so you can adjust for Z squareness)
Lasercut out of 6mm MDF, then glued together.

title: Customizable solder spool holder WITH FILLET!

description.text: I took sudhir's excellent customizable solder holder and added a fillet to the area where the clip meets the wall using a fillet library (file included). I felt that this intersection was a little weak and might one day break. Unfortunately, fillet libraries a slow in OpenSCAD, so you might need to be patient. Open the file and set the parameters at the top for your spool. A faster way to check what the final product will look like is to use sudhir's original model and then just copy the parameter values into this scad file.

This is a dual sided low torque hex bit driver.

The parameters for each hex bit socket can be controlled independently, allowing for one driver to fit two different bit sizes.

This can also be used as a nut holder.

As always, you should use a well calibrated printer.

I built mine for use with 1/4" and 5/32" hex bits for working with low torque requirements.

The bits should fit into the sockets with little effort, but they should not wiggle excessively.

The magnets should be slightly smaller than the diameter of the bit. I used 3/16" ($0.16 US) and 1/8" ($0.25 US) diameter magnets with a height of 1/8".

To secure the magnets in their holes, any type of gel glue should work. I used G-Lock BLU-GLU, because I already had some, and it worked well.

To finish it off, I sprayed it with 4 coats of Plasti Dip to give it a softer, more comfortable rubber feel.

title: ToMa - ZMR LED Strip, bumper, landing gear [v4]

description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/gybTxXMq4Ab

The landing gear is the first thing that breaks for me.. So I took them all off. Then it was so flat that even a little grass keeps me from taking off. And I also smashed a cam.

This BRUTAL doodad solves both issues AND lets you mount an awesome taillight. More for beginners/often crashers....

If it breaks you don't have to take apart the quad because the bolt head is exposed (not in between plates like the middle standoffs) . Print a few extra so you can pop one in right after a crash! 30 second repair job!

ENJOY!

Version 4
Curved support did not reach front plate

Version 3

  • Added extra support where plates meet
  • Increased size of mounting holes to reduce the need to drill
  • Sliced out support section to allow bottom plate to slide in
  • Added add'l holes for zipties

Turn upside down and then mount. This will sandwich between the two bottom plates.

Remember to print 2 ! (Front / Back)

Luggage label with embossed text

Derived from a SCAD based version. I couldn't get the SCAD version to work well for a tri-colour printer, so I re-used the base tag, and added 3D text using Sketch 3D tool instead. See instructions for how to use.

In the zip file is an STL file for a blank label and a Sketch skb file.
You will need to know how to use Sketch.

To print a label with text
1) Open the Sketch file
2) Delete the example text
3) Add your own text using Sketch 3D text option under tool menu, and place onto label.

What you do next depends if you want to print the label with one colour or print the base and text in separate colours.

Print all one colour
1) Select the Label and all the text and export to STL
2) Generate G-Code using your favourite slicer programme

Print in two colours
1) Select just the text and export as to STL
2) Generate a combined G-Code file using the existing Label.stl and the text.stl you just generated. I used the recent version of Slic3r to do this

description.text: Credit for the design of this model goes to dragonator. All that I did was go through the assembly and adjust the tolerances for a little better fitment, trimmed away some of the excess so it can be made with less material and split up a bunch of the pieces to optimize it for 3D printing and to allow for everything to be made without using any supports. All the pieces are to be printed in the orientation that they are in. For examples of painted guns and to get the great looking decals please see http://ytec3d.com/laser-pistol/
Refer to the picture with the exploded view to see how it is assembled.

author: Mdavisgtm

title: Zortrax active cooling of extruder gear

description.text: I have an Zortrax M200P that has been modified by myself to allow using all the other plastics available on the market today, PLA, ABS Nylon, Wood and metal filled and just as with my "UP Plus Pro" I found the stepper motor of the extruder getting too hot over long print times and transmitting the heat through the feeder gear and pre-softening the filament causing strip-out, so I added this mod to use compressed air to actively cool the gear, it works great just as it does on my other machines

I designed the plastic part to be printed in as solid a setting as you can, then glue in a small cut section of plastic tubing, OD 4.5 x ID 2.5, cut at 45 degree angles on both ends to redirect the air stream, tap the top hole to M5 for a SMC, KGS04-M5, SUS MALE CONNECTOR, 4mm TUBE X M5 and 2 M3 x 20 socket head cap screws mount.
I use a compressor piped from my garage at about 5PSI just a wisper.
I also placed a small bit of clear plastic tape to the face of the hole to keep the air circulating, this may not be necessary.
Also installed a Z-Temp that works fantastic!
http://z-temp.co/
I highly recommend this!

title: Triforce Pendant (Remix) - Originally designed by Cowkitty.

description.text:
I really liked this design by Cowkitty and wanted to make a way that the TriForce pieces could be removed and put back. When I tried editing the original file I found it had some extra geometry and wasn't perfectly symmetrical so I decided to take some measurements and rebuild it from scratch. I made the largest dimension of the outer most triangle equal to 50 meters. From there based all inner triangles on the mid point length between them. I included my Sketchup file from when I finished the Triforce piece, but before working on the hanger.

I could never quite get the original hanger down, which I think was better than what I came up with. I created files for different sizes of the TriForce Pieces. I found that .95 scale was too loose, and .97 scale was loose for one piece, but snug for the other two, so I included a .96 scale piece which might be just right. lol. When too snug I just used my trusty Solidoodle spatula to remove it. It might be worth consideration to go looser and insert magnets in the frame and on the pieces. When scaling the TriForce pieces I only changed the Y and X axis, but kept original height.

I figured having separate pieces allows the maker to color them as they please, and even print using different filaments. Possibly transparent or glow in the dark.
Print the Frame piece and choose the preferred fit for the TriForce triangles. I recommend .96 scale for a semi loose fit.

comments.text: How come the file size is 10x larger than any other files its size and construction? I cant get it to upload, I think because of its size.
comments.author: Jeff000

comments.text:
most likely due to the fact it has way more vertices to make the shape than any other file or model its size.
Each vertices is a data-point x/y/z connecting edges to make planes and overall shape. the more there are the more data needed to make the file.
If it were a solid model with no holes/gaps or not "voronoi style", less would be required to make the shape thus the large file size.
happens with really high resolution models too.

author: nanard_baudon

description.text:
Tricopter with wheeled undercarriage that allows running take-offs and landings. This machine had been created to be as cheap in construction and flying and repairable as possible, yet represent flight dynamics somewhat similar to a full-scale helicopter (so very simple flight controller that provides only minimal stabilization, and wooden booms that ocassionaly warp due to humidity, adding a bit of random drift that has to be compensated by a pilot). Tail rotor is lifted to protect it from contact with ground and obstacles while on the ground, and also for keeping it out of ground effect on landing, allowing very smooth tail-first touchdowns.

Horizontal bar on the video is a visual reference, showing frame bank angle relative to terrain and camera, as camera is not mounted rigidly and can tilt a bit itself.

Flight time is around 6-7 minutes with 2200mah 3s battery and 10-12 minutes with 4200mah, though machine becomes heavy with its weight so flying on a windy day can be challenging, especially when turning into tailwind or trying a high hover.

Flight video:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SC4wt_plVMo

Models are designed with sketchup for 10mm wooden booms.

On the first picture this is prototype version without vibration dampening camera mount, that is shown on other pictures. Flight video is captured with cameras mount installed.

------ update:

Since summer had come to its end, and the machine is still in one piece (though it had flown every weekend at least for an hour), i've decided to remove "work in progress" sign. It flies fine, especially with 4200 battery (it can possibly handle larger ones as well). I've pushed it to the limit from time to time, had a very rough landing once due to pilot error (chassis absorbed all impact energy with only minor damage caused to one of wheels, and there was no damage at all dealt to other parts of the machine) so it seems it's pretty much safe to fly. The only problem is the lack of avionics. So, maybe it is a good idea to replace KK 5.5 board with multiwii.

------ update 2:

The winter is coming, along with snow, rains, humidity and other stuff it's best to avoid contact with. So, there should be an all-weather version to handle it. Why not, just put electronics into sealed containers, so it will survive a crash landing in deep snow. This time i will also use aluminium booms, cause wood will most likely bend randomly in such conditions.

Stay tuned.

I used cheap and popular dt-750 motors from hobbyking, rcx 20A opto ESC with simonk firmware, sky holic HDS-577 metal gear servo, KK 5.5 flight controller, Frsky d8r2plus diversity receiver, 11x4,7 APC props, boscam 500mw 5,8G transmitter, boscam cloud spirit circular polarized 5,8G antennas, sj4000 for flight recording, sony effio 600tvl cam for flight control link. BEC is a 7805 with 2 capacitors. Frame is assembled with 3mm bolts of various sizes (12-40mm) and nuts. Wooden parts of the frame are covered with colored scotch tape for protection against humidity (to a certain extent) and better aesthetics.

Frame parts are designed for 10mm booms, i used 400mm for side motors, 500mm for rear one and 200mm for cameras mount. Aluminium booms can be used for better rigidness, not sure how it will affect vibrations though. Aquarium air tube, 2 sided 3m tape and rubber bands are used in cameras mount for vibration reduction.

If you decide to print it, please pay attention to motor mounts and tail part alignment while printing: all parts should take load along threads direction. So motor mounts should be printed horizontally and at 100% infill, or they most likely will fail due to vibration. Tail part should be positioned on its back, so the part where tail motor mount is attached is on the table, and printed with support.

title: Toilet Model originally designed by Haihuynh.

description.text:
I took the original model and separated the bowl from the tank for easier printing. I removed the loop so it is more of a stand up model than an ornament, and I extruded inward from the handle. There is still a overhang, but it looks more solid and prints less stringy with extrusion machines. I also patched up the inside of the bowl. It was not manifold so I went through and connected the surfaces, and ran it through NetFabb Service until it no longer filled in the entire bowl. I think it turned out pretty well. I can now print golden toilets for anyone who wants one. :)

In retrospect maybe I should have cut it into three parts so the bowl doesn't have that wider part that the tank sits on printed with the bowl creating a massive overhang.

title: Belt clamp for Mostly Printed CNC / MultiTool

description.text:
Update 8/27/2015
After seeing the remix of this http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:981260 , I made a rev2 version of the grooved clamp to incorporate this idea & made the hole and edges round. I also added some welds around the clamp to make it more solid.

Here are 3 different options for a belt clamp to use instead of 1 of the zip ties at the corner blocks or attach to hook on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:853977.

I am starting to put this on my machine now & the 2nd & 3rd photos show it attached using the standard method & using the Mechanical Belt Tensioner option. It does not look like it will work well with the Mechanical Belt Tensioner as that clip hits the bearing on side that gets closer to the end. The long version clamp is probably too long to use with this, but included it in case it is useful for some other project.

These clamp designs originated from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:627214 & http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:643799

You will need 8 of these for the Mostly Printed CNC project. I would print one of each 1st to see which works best for you Print either of the versions you wish to use. The small clips only weigh about .04oz each.

One of the designs is printed in pairs so the belt will be going the same way thru the clamp on each end.

remixed_from.author: nigeljohnson73
remixed_from.title: B+ Pi Cam Ultimaker 2 timelapse harness

title: Rigidbot Frame Mount for B+ Pi Cam Timelapse Harness

description.text:
I really loved the design of the Time-lapse Harness for the Ultimaker, so I decided to go and model my own mount in OpenSCAD. Should be quite stable, though it is too big to fit in between the two knuckles in the bottom corners, and it's too big for the bottom. I can adjust those if anyone wants, or anyone can edit the Scad file and edit it themselves.

For the Camera, the original design says to use the Mount Block (for some reason not called mount_block.stl and instead called pi_cam_mount_v2.stl) and a Long Bolt. Because this design is so stable and is physically incompatible with said mount block, do not print the block and print just a standard bolt. Full list of parts in Instructions.

The scad file has the original file in a absolute position relative to my computer, so you'll need to download it and link that file your self if you want to edit it.

I printed on my stock Rigidbot with these settings:
.2 Layer Height
10% Infil
Supports on.
You CAN print without supports, but you will get a terrible grip from the top "Hook".

List of Parts:

Pi:
1x Rigidbot Hook (This Thing)
1x Pi Frame Front (pi_frame_front.stl)
1x Pi Frame Back (pi_frameback.stl)
1x Standard Bolt (bolt-_big.st)

Camera:
1x Rigidbot Hook (This Thing)
1x Angle Mount (pi_cam_mount_blockv2.stl)
2x or 3x Bolts for arm (bolt-_big.stl)
2x or 3x Arms (pi_cam_arm_v2.stl) Must match amount of bolts above.
1x Pi Camera Mount (pi_cam_mountv2.stl)
2x Extra Bolts IN ADDITION to the 2 or 3 above (bolt-_big.stl)

description.text:
UPDATE 19-07: Just made the propeller from ABS. really happy with the build quality. The white parts you see is just from me sanding it (although obviously not needed). As you can see the detail is great: layer height .1

UPDATE (16.07):
Be sure to get the "propeller 3.stl" file.
I've remodeled the whole propeller surface from scratch. Made two separate surfaces for the inner and outer airfoil to achieve better transitions and radius.

A small propeller head to measure wind speed and detect drafts. This is the first iteration, there is still a lot of work to be done, such as optimize airfoil shape, radius at tip and so on.

UPDATE (16.07):
Readjusted the settings:
Number of perimeters: 1 (this way the annoying defect on the propeller should be minimized.

All settings (for those who don't know what the normal print in Robox is):
Nozzle: 0.3
Perimeter: 0.4
Infill: 0.4
Solid infill: 0.3
Fill density: 30%
Solid layers on top: 3
Solid layers on bottom: 3
Speed:
-Perimeter: 25mm/s
-External Perimeter: 25mm/s
-Infill: 30mm/s

Created with Autodesk Inventor Ed and printed on a Robox at normal settings in PLA.

comments.text:
Nicely done.
How did you approach modeling it?
comments.author: siderits

comments.text:
Well this is actually the third iteration already. The first one I made was just a simple helicoid surface which I thickened. For the second version I lofted an arc along the helix and for the third I took a real airfoil shape and lofted it along a helical curve. The helix does a half turn and the pitch is the height of the base cylinder. I think I'll reduce that to .48 turns to clear the particle pathway straight down from the tip to the bottom. I also plan on adding ridges to guide the air when the velocity is getting higher.
If you have more questions I'll be happy to help.
comments.author: siderits

comments.text: Fences used to be common on ship propellers (and maybe wind turbines too), but I think they've been replaced with cupping of the blades in more modern designs.

It's never a bad idea to have spare parts for your MakerBot lying around. I have an old batch 2 MakerBot with outdated z-guides which make removing the z-stage really difficult. Luckily the new version of the z-guide is super easy to print out. Also interesting is the x-rod bracket. Upgrading to the newer, skinnier rods is a little easier now and you need four less lasercut parts. Yay. Hardware upgrades over the internet! If you want to make any of your own parts the dxf's are all online (or in the repository http://svn.makerbot.com/).
Print! (I suggest the z-guides if you have an oldie like me).

remixed_from.author: tonyyoungblood
remixed_from.title: High Tide Bathtub Overflow Drain Plate - Old Version

title: High Tide Bathtub Overflow Drain Plate - New Design!

description.text:
Here is a new and improved version of my old bathtub overflow plate. (See source link below for old version.)

This new one can be printed without support structures.

The plate on a standard bathtub "overflow drain" pulls water from the bottom. This means the maximum water level can never go above the bottom of the overflow plate.

To increase the maximum water level, I created this "High Tide" overflow plate that drains from the top. Now you can add a few inches of water to your bath!

I did some finishing on mine with XTC 3D Brush On epoxy and white enamel spray paint.

Use 100% Silicone Bathroom Caulk to get a good seal. See instructions for specifics.

Note: In the pictured version, you see little drain holes in the top. I removed these in the final version. They were unnecessary and hard to finish around.

Coming soon: A one hole version!

I recommend printing without support structures, layer height .2mm, 15 percent or more infill, 4 top/bottom horizontal shells, 3 vertical shells.

Use the screws that came with your old overflow plate. Temporarily mount and examine fit. This will help determine how much silicone you'll need.

Remove the plate and fill the back channels with 100% silicone kitchen & bathroom caulk, applying as needed to make a good seal. Let dry overnight.

Right before you mount, dab a little bit of silicone in the screw holes.

Mount and enjoy a higher water level!

comments.text: Looks nice, I used the old 'one hole' version.. would you mind to update this version to have one hole? Thanks

Piece designed specifically for 1970's Honda CT90. Version 1 was the very first thing I had ever designed. I used Photoshop CC to covert a picture to 3d. The results are fairly close to version 1. Lots of little flaws.

Version 3 was designed entirely in Sketchup. I used a phenolic spacer from my fathers CT90 and a decent digital caliper. Version 3 spacer is the one people should be using.

As good as gets in plastic. Stay tuned, it may be coming in aluminum soon.

Update 5/20/2016: I have cast this piece in aluminum several times and not happy with the overall results. Its still a work in progress. A picture of the aluminum spacer of my best cast and 3d printed piece are included here.

I have printed this part in both ABS and PLA. Infill is typically 30% for strength.

For better overall finish, use no less than 3 top and bottom layers and atleast 2 perimeters.

For anyone who has printed this part, please respond to this thing and let me know if anything needs to be changed.

author: srmarisol

description.text:
The Sunsphere was built for the 1982 World's Fair in Knoxville, Tennessee. It stands in World's Fair Park in the center of Knoxville. http://worldsfairpark.org/worlds-fair-sunsphere.html I run the 3D Printer at a children's museum in Knoxville, and wanted to create a custom model that we could use to demonstrate the operation of the printer and then give away or sell. Everyone in the region knows this building. You can go inside and look out the windows!

Having this thing on display or actively printing gets kids and adults interested in additive manufacturing, and important industry in this region. We also conduct "Intro to 3D Printing" classes and camps for kids.

This model was made with Tinkercad and printed with a Makerbot Replicator 2.

Made with Tinkercad. I started with a faceted sphere (by T3K1T). After adding a square stem, I built a single wall of trusses using stretched out cubes. I duplicated the truss walls and arranged them using a hexagon to help with the symmetry. The trusses don't exactly match the original, but the original Sunsphere has horizontal trusses that wouldn't print cleanly on the Replicator without supports. The first version did not have the hex base plate, but I added it and it looks much cleaner. I also made a version with a loop for hanging, which we gave to our board members last Christmas.

The example in the photo was printed upright in clear PLA on a Makerbot 2 with 0.2mm layers. No supports or raft needed.

comments.text: Awesome! I live in Knoxville, and I can't wait to make this myself!

remixed_from.author: eiPionezero
remixed_from.title: Cable chain, perfect fit and rounded edges

description.text:
I removed some sections of the links just to consume less plastic. I also changed the orientation since the vertical position from the original made a really weak structure.
You still need to print it with 100% infill, 0.2 layer height, and with supports. Add Brim if you are using ABS, 3mm is enough.

This design also reduces print time by 40%.

Yeah, you will be able to see the cables inside, its not that aesthetic.

Update: Added some pictures of a few of them printed, I'll update with another image when I install them on my printer!

Update 2: Added a nema 17 adapter for the chains. The link in the adapter is at an angle because Im using Gregs extruder, which puts your motor at a 26,5 angle. You will understand better when I upload pics of the chain mounted.

Update 3: Added another orientation for the Nema 17 adapter. I also added an elbow for the chain, if you need your chain to make a 90º turn.

comments.text: This design does reduce printing time but with less adhesion surface it also needs a brim... So more cleanup.
comments.author: Tito1337

comments.text: Just print them in PLA and forget about bed adhesion (if you have a heated bed of course).
comments.author: Tito1337

comments.text: I am printing in PLA on a bed at 60°C, but I need to buy new blue tape... because white painters tape does not adhere without a brim
comments.author: Filar3D

comments.text: When I use PLA and a heated bed, it gets so stuck that I have to wait to the bed to cool down to remove the piece.I dont use blue painters tape, just the glass.
comments.author: Tito1337

comments.text: Maybe I will try a glass sheet, I thougt everybody recommends blue tape directly on the aluminium bed
comments.author: Filar3D

comments.text:
Try the glass sheet and a pritt glue stick (large size is easiest) applied to the glass. No heating.
Let the stick dry for 5 mins before you print. A thin layer is sufficient.
The glue cleans up in water. No more probs and easy to remove with a spatula.

remixed_from.title: Lab ATX power supply skeleton case

title: Lab ATX Power Supply Front Panel.. Remix

description.text:
Remix of the front panel for the Lab ATX Power Supply Skeleton Case by james_III

I redesigned the front panel to install a CC/CV programmable power supply module from eBay, 2-20v at 2A, i didn't use the guts of the ATX supply, instead i installed an open frame supply i also found on eBay with a 12v and 5v output and used a small boost converter to bring up the 12v output to 23v for the max input of the power supply module, works great! I could have also used a 24v supply but the ones that were small enough and adjustable to bring it down to the max input of 23v for the module were a lot more expensive.

I included a 5v USB jack i salvaged and put a fuse holder in the rear of the ATX housing that i gutted to hold my power supply, i kept the fan and IEC power inlet along with the input filtering on the back of the inlet to feed the new supply that i mounted inside. The reason was i didn't have a good working spare ATX supply and now i have more reliable output voltage, no load needed on the 5v rail which would just create extra heat, etc.

Holds a cable to the back of a desk.
Screw this clamp into the bottom back of the desktop. Pre-drill the hole to prevent the screw from pushing out the desk-wood.
I chose LAYWOO-D3 to match my wood coloured desk, but black or brown plastic might also look just as good. The slot down the middle allows the arms to spring open wide enough to accept the cable. Sizes can be changed in scad file to suite your desk and cable and screw.

I used LAYWOO-D3 on a Makerbot ToM with the following settings:
Skeinforge 50
Infill = 100%
Layer height = 0.40 mm
Shells=1
Feedrate=30 mm/s
Travel=30 mm/s
Temperature=220 C Then wait a while before pulling off the print because LAYWOO-D3 takes a while to cool down and become stiff.

JJ's sonic scredriver multiple attachable parts

This is a model that I haven't been working on for long, but I think it has great potential. Originally, it floated but not upright. Since then, I have changed the shape of the hull, which is now not as tall as it used to be, to fix this problem. The boat now floats upright. I will keep posting updates as I continue to work on this model. Hope you like it.

When I finish this model, I will begin dissecting it into several smaller pieces for people like me who have a small printer.

To make this model, I started how any good scientist would, I ran some tests. I began by printing a simple 1x1 cm cube with my default print settings. I then printed a 2x2 cm cube with the same print settings. After this, I filled a glass with water before dropping the smaller cube in the water. Sure enough, it floated. Next, I dropped the larger cube in the water, just to be sure that the size of the printed object didn't affect the ability for it to float. The larger cube also float.

Next, I decided to start getting creative. I hopped onto my computer and started modeling. I decided that just setting coins on my boat would be a little boring. The first thing I made was a barrel. This barrel had a hole in it that I could put coins into. I hoped that this would make my entry not only more appealing, but also more importantly, more creative.

The next model I created was the actual pirate ship. My process of modeling is probably different than that of others. I started by just making a pirate ship that didn't have any detail besides the general shape. It was pretty much a 3-dimensional version of what a little kid might draw on a piece of paper. It looked pretty bad. But this was my plan, it's all a part of my process. This first model acted as a sort of skeleton. After this, I began to add a lot of detail. I started adding ripples to the sails, smoother seams, etc.

I tested the hull at a lake. I set U.S. dimes on top of it until it sunk. I managed to fit 10 dimes on top of the hull, that's 22.68 g. I probably could have gotten more before it sunk, but the main problem was that it became too difficult to balance. I printed the hull at the maximum size that would fit on my Replicator Mini build plate. If printed larger, the point of balance will grow and this problem can be overcome. I then filled one of my barrels with 10 U.S. dimes and set it on top of the hull. This was even more difficult because the weight of the dimes was in one place, where before, this weight was spread out.

I printed this model the largest I possibly could with my current build plate size. The dimensions were:
hull: 50.36 x 51.43 x 116.71 mm

This model is still a work in progress, but I hope to finish it soon.

I present to you TankBender, your favorite robot mounted to a tank and ready for action.
"Hey, sexy mama... Wanna kill all humans?" (from Futurama: Season 1, Episode 3)

This is my first big project using my FlashForge Creator Pro and is still very much a work-in-progress, I just felt it was time to go ahead and start sharing it. I have spent many hours designing the parts in OpenSCAD and printing test parts to ensure everything works as expected however different printers and filament can cause variations so you may need to modify source files to get everything to fit. The base of the tank was heavily inspired by thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:673920 although I have re-designed all of the parts from the ground up using OpenSCAD and improved most of them in the process. The Bender head was something that I just thought would be very cool while I was designing the base. I will be continually improving this design and adding new features.

I plan to design an Android app to control the tank including sending video back from the camera although I am new to Android programming so it will likely take some time before that is done and anyone with experience that would like to contribute is welcome. Everything in the tank will be powered via a Raspberry Pi and arduino controllers and will use a LiPo battery (currently testing with 11.1 V battery). I plan to eventually have an airsoft mechanism which will be mounted behind the teeth, the hole in the teeth will have the barrel sticking out and will be designed to look like a cigar. The visor part of the head is designed to hold a 6mm laser pointer in each eye and a Raspberry Pi official camera which is mounted between the eyes (see pic of head parts showing back of visor with camera in place and pic showing lasers turned on).

The base of the tank will hold the Raspberry Pi as well as other electronics and the Head will rotate like a tank turret. I am still playing with which motors/gearboxes I will be using to power the base and turret but testing with the Tamiya 70168 double gearbox for the base. The gearbox currently mounts perfectly in one end of the base using the gearbox_plate file included. The track sections were printed with TPU filament so they are extremely strong and flexible which gives them more traction than if printed with other filaments, if you can print with NinjaFlex that may work as well (maybe better/maybe not) but I had trouble printing with that. The wheel holders are designed to be fitted 2 together to form an end, one of the wheel holders is designed so you can stop the print at Z height 7.6 and then you can add a bearing which will be embedded when finished while the other can have a bearing inserted when done which can also be replaced if needed.

I have learned a lot in this process including programming/designing in OpenSCAD as well as learning a lot about designing 3D prints to print successfully. I will continue to learn more as I learn about programming for Android and get more involved with the electronics to control the various mechanisms.

I will include a parts list for everything needed to assemble once I decide on the final parts. I will also add the source OpenSCAD files as soon as I am done with some cleanup/commenting.

Trying to get it to fit a different dome? Scale it. Print it upside down. and pause the print after the first few layers. See if your dome fits the ring. If not rescale and try again. If its a good fit. Flip it back over and print as usual.
